answers.answer: Hello,your insulin dose needs to be adjusted to lower your blood sugars.Your doctor should have explained to you how to do this.What dose are you taking.  Are you taking a mixed insulin or basal (long acting - as background) / bolus (short acting - to be taken before meals)Typically insulin dose will be increased by 2 - 5 units (5 units if you are very far from target, and 2 units, if you are close), with blood sugar being observed.  Ideally this is done under supervision from your health care provided or a certified diabetes educator.Would recommend the book "Think Like a Pancreas", "Using Insulin" by John Walsh, or Diabetes Solutions by Dr. Richard Bernstein.  All describe how to safely adjust insulin doses.Please also combine your metformin and insulin with a lower carb, moderate protein, and high healthy fats diet.  Regular exercise will also help.

I started taking insulin about a month ago, started with 5 units.  Have now increased 2 units every few days now at 15 and my sugars are consistently average 230 -270.  I also take Metformin twice a day.  Super frustrated with my numbers....any thiughts?

Hello,your insulin dose still needs to be adjusted.While your blood sugars are so high, you may need to increase by say 5 units every 3 days or so.  Once your blood sugars are in the range of about 130-150, then go back to increasing by 2 units every 3 days.What insulins are you taking?  Are you taking both a short (before eating)and a long acting insulin (night time and morning, depennding on the insulin)?Please make sure you are following low carb, moderate protein, higher (healthy) fats diet.
